abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and the institutional development
            impact is substantial. Nonetheless, several lessons are
            drawn from the project: 1) Capacity building in the areas of
            financial management, and procurement should be part of the
            project design, together with an assessment of the capacity
            of implementing agencies at appraisal time, and include
            built-in safeguards in the form of end-use audit reviews.
            Additionally, performance indicators need to be agreed at
            appraisal, as well as project costs to establish benchmark
            values. 2) Operational aspects suggest that regional
            projects should rather be replaced with province specific
            projects, to reduce complex geographical issues, number of
            implementing agencies, and, to better address the province
            macroeconomic framework, while minimizing long-term
            implementation periods. 3) Administrative aspects call for
            coordination mechanisms, and adequate monitoring -
            particularly for projects funded by a variety of donors,
            with parallel financing arrangements - to be defined at
            appraisal. Guarantees for continuity of key managerial, and
            technical staff should be contained in the legal documents,
            to include as well a clause in the Project Agreement to
            minimize political interference in managerial aspects, but
            agree on the selection criteria for essential project staff.

18154999.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Population and reproductive health,Health system performance,Child health,Gender
18154999.trustfund: TF031938-PAKISTAN - SECOND FAMILY HEALTH PROJECT,TF023105-PHRD-POPULATION PROJECT II,TF033367-PAKISTAN - SECOND FAMILY HEALTH,TF033365-PAKISTAN - SECOND FAMILY HEALTH,TF033364-PAKISTAN - SECOND FAMILY HEALTH,TF031939-PAKISTAN - SECOND FAMILY HEALTH PROJECT,TF033366-PAKISTAN - SECOND FAMILY HEALTH`,TF032802-PAKISTAN - HEALTH

abstracts.cdata!:
The project has the main objective of
            improving the health status of the population of the two
            provinces through assisting with the implementation of the
            provincial health development programs. The health programs
            will increase the emphasis on: (a) primary health; and b)
            preventive and promotional services. The project will
            finance key parts of the programs concentrating on: (i)
            strengthening primary health services from the village to
            the district level, focusing on improved maternal and child
            health services; (ii) staff development, focusing on
            improved staff capabilities and performance and increasing
            the number of female paramedical staff; and (iii) management
            and organizational development, focusing on improved
            management capabilities. The project will finance:
            construction and expansion of training facilities and
            limited health facility upgrading; furniture, equipment and
            transport; contraceptives; training costs; technical
            assistance; and incremental recurrent costs including medicines.
